content: How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In Stephanie Georgopulos Blocked Unblock Follow Following Sep 11, 2013 waiting for the world C ross-legged on the cold, tiled floor of a hospital corridor, I heard myself talking to God for the first time in fourteen years. Sure, I’ve said God’s name a million and a half times since I was thirteen, but in the blasphemous sort of way—like God is a friend at a party who I secretly despise, who I spend the evening in a corner gossiping about. But this was different. Now I was engaging. Now I was acknowledging. Now I was asking for favors. An hour earlier, I was speaking with doctors and hearing words that were never meant to be said on a Sunday night. Words like “artery damage,” and “accident,” and “amputation.” He lay on a gurney with a rational facial expression. I don’t know what my own looked like, but I wanted it to be calm. Reassuring. I knew it had to be that way, from books I’ve read or from monologues I’ve heard on television. You have to be the strong one, now. For him. So I pretended best I could, and when he was wheeled into an X-ray room and I had to wait outside, I crumpled up on the floor and began to talk at god. I didn’t know what to say, it’d been so long. Just “please.” Please and please and please. I’m not religious, you know, I don’t have the right prayers for the wrong situations. I just know that then, at that moment, I needed to believe in something bigger than medicine and man. These things would save him I knew, but I needed more than that. Voodoo. Witchcraft. Divine intervention. Anything. We needed all the energy in the world to get through the night. As more information came in, my sudden religious fervor dissipated. I went back to believing in doctors and in friends and in us. We could get through this; we would. Still, I understood something I hadn’t before, which is: there is no shame in recognizing that you have no control. There is nothing wrong with asking for help. Sometimes you need to summon more strength than what is inside of you. I don’t know where that strength comes from or who is responsible for it. I don’t know who you should address in these matters. All I know is that the next time I see someone cross-legged on cold tile and praying for something, I will understand what she’s looking for. Buy Stephanie’s Kindle Single, Some Things I Did for Money .
title_html: How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In

How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In

Stephanie Georgopulos
Sep 11, 2013

Cross-legged on the cold, tiled floor of a hospital corridor, I heard myself talking to God for the first time in fourteen years.

Sure, I’ve said God’s name a million and a half times since I was thirteen, but in the blasphemous sort of way—like God is a friend at a party who I secretly despise, who I spend the evening in a corner gossiping about.

But this was different. Now I was engaging. Now I was acknowledging. Now I was asking for favors.

An hour earlier, I was speaking with doctors and hearing words that were never meant to be said on a Sunday night. Words like “artery damage,” and “accident,” and “amputation.” He lay on a gurney with a rational facial expression. I don’t know what my own looked like, but I wanted it to be calm. Reassuring. I knew it had to be that way, from books I’ve read or from monologues I’ve heard on television. You have to be the strong one, now. For him.

So I pretended best I could, and when he was wheeled into an X-ray room and I had to wait outside, I crumpled up on the floor and began to talk at god. I didn’t know what to say, it’d been so long. Just “please.” Please and please and please. I’m not religious, you know, I don’t have the right prayers for the wrong situations. I just know that then, at that moment, I needed to believe in something bigger than medicine and man. These things would save him I knew, but I needed more than that. Voodoo. Witchcraft. Divine intervention. Anything. We needed all the energy in the world to get through the night.

As more information came in, my sudden religious fervor dissipated. I went back to believing in doctors and in friends and in us. We could get through this; we would. Still, I understood something I hadn’t before, which is: there is no shame in recognizing that you have no control. There is nothing wrong with asking for help. Sometimes you need to summon more strength than what is inside of you. I don’t know where that strength comes from or who is responsible for it. I don’t know who you should address in these matters. All I know is that the next time I see someone cross-legged on cold tile and praying for something, I will understand what she’s looking for.

Buy Stephanie’s Kindle Single, Some Things I Did for Money.

Thanks to charlotte druckman.

title: How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In
content_html:
How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In

Stephanie Georgopulos
Sep 11, 2013

Cross-legged on the cold, tiled floor of a hospital corridor, I heard myself talking to God for the first time in fourteen years.

Sure, I’ve said God’s name a million and a half times since I was thirteen, but in the blasphemous sort of way—like God is a friend at a party who I secretly despise, who I spend the evening in a corner gossiping about.

But this was different. Now I was engaging. Now I was acknowledging. Now I was asking for favors.

An hour earlier, I was speaking with doctors and hearing words that were never meant to be said on a Sunday night. Words like “artery damage,” and “accident,” and “amputation.” He lay on a gurney with a rational facial expression. I don’t know what my own looked like, but I wanted it to be calm. Reassuring. I knew it had to be that way, from books I’ve read or from monologues I’ve heard on television. You have to be the strong one, now. For him.

So I pretended best I could, and when he was wheeled into an X-ray room and I had to wait outside, I crumpled up on the floor and began to talk at god. I didn’t know what to say, it’d been so long. Just “please.” Please and please and please. I’m not religious, you know, I don’t have the right prayers for the wrong situations. I just know that then, at that moment, I needed to believe in something bigger than medicine and man. These things would save him I knew, but I needed more than that. Voodoo. Witchcraft. Divine intervention. Anything. We needed all the energy in the world to get through the night.

As more information came in, my sudden religious fervor dissipated. I went back to believing in doctors and in friends and in us. We could get through this; we would. Still, I understood something I hadn’t before, which is: there is no shame in recognizing that you have no control. There is nothing wrong with asking for help. Sometimes you need to summon more strength than what is inside of you. I don’t know where that strength comes from or who is responsible for it. I don’t know who you should address in these matters. All I know is that the next time I see someone cross-legged on cold tile and praying for something, I will understand what she’s looking for.
